text: I was going to cover the Everest
climbing season from everything that
happened but the main focus was to sort
of show how difficult it is to get up to
the top of the mountain when you're
you're up there you completely by
yourself you know you people can't come
in you know get you down it's the
altitude makes it physically impossible
to move yourself let alone move anyone
else as well getting from base camp -
camp 1 which is the first of four camps
who is yeah
physically absolutely debilitating by
the time you get to the top you are
exhausted and in fact going along was
just you know you're falling from one
leg to the other the first part in
climbing Everest is getting through the
ice wall and it's known as kind of one
of the most dangerous bits because now
you have huge blocks of ice and this
thing is it's moving it's almost like
it's alive so you're physically
completely empty and then at the same
time you're trying to watch all these
blocks of ice and watch everything
moving around you we arrived at camp 1 I
just put my bag inside the tent and then
I stood out of the the tent and
everything started to move and it felt
as though it felt like the glacier was
sliding off the mountain and we were sat
on its back and it the whole mountain
just came to life there's big lumps of
ice that are the size of houses falling
off these mountains and coming straight
towards you we could only see about five
meters in front of us it was a complete
whiteout so we knew that all of this ice
was coming directly towards us and
behind us we've got a crevasse that's
hundreds of meters deep and we were just
expecting to either be killed by a lump
of ice or thrown into the crevasse yeah
I've come close to being shot before
I've come close to explosions going off
but that was
that was the closest I've come to
accepting I'm gonna die
the earthquake lasted 40 seconds by
itself then the Avalanche you started we
were waiting for the avalanches for you
know a minute and the rumble was just
getting louder and louder and louder and
there's just nothing you can do it's
this feeling of complete entrapment
Europe camp one on Mount Everest and
then we learn that our home base camp
everything we had anew and our safe
haven and the part of the entire climb
that was supposed to be safe and
supposed to always be there so you know
it's there has gone base camp is quite a
long stretching piece of land and the
bit in the middle is exactly where my
camp was that was my sin
and then there's two counts either side
and it was just gone absolutely
obliterated and you you go over the next
ridge and it's worse and over the next
ridge and it's worse and it just you
know you're walking in a complete daze
thinking yeah this is my home this is
where I'm supposed to spend the next
four weeks and nothing's left
mountaineering is dangerous we know that
and I came here to show that Everest is
not a placing for rich people the
mountain is supposed to be dangerous but
Basecamp is supposed to be the safe that
